page.lettertext:
fol.158r
bis
Maye it please your good L. to be advertised
t
I arryved in
Flushing
e 15
th
of this monneth, and
e nexte daye after came
to
Middleborough,
where I thought it very requisite to tary
t
daye, to co
m
uniate in pryvate w
th
e chiefe of
t
Province
and to feele theyr inclination to her
Ma
ties
demaundes, wherby
I might conjecture howe
e rest would disgest it when I came
to this place. I founde
t
my coming was foreknowne unto
them and allso what I would propose, wherewth they seemed by theyr
talke to be very muche mooved, especially
t
her Ma
tie
would
drawe awaye those troupes which they had armed, and payed and
newly sent to service. What passed on both sydes in our
conference together, it is but needlesse to rehearse, because yt
tendes to
t
effect which I will signifie to your L. in my
dealing w
th
the
states.
I came to the Haghe
e 19 daye
and had audience the 21; but no aunswer at
t
tyme to
e
matter of my message. For they observe theyr wonted manner
in affayres of any moment, not to aunswere on the sudden.
Onely soe muche they signified
t
her Ma
ties
motion was exceding
prejudiciall to
e state of these Countries, not offering at that
tyme to debate yt further w
th
me. Howbeit
e second daye
after there were twoe deputed by
e rest to co
m
unicate
w
th
me pryvatly,
M
r
Barnevelt
and
M
r
Cromstrien
;
who gave me plainely to understaunde
t
for the troupes
which they had raysed, they might not by any meanes forgoe
them at this tyme. They had beene very long sutors to her
Ma
tie
for them, theyr expences had bin great in
e onely
transporting and arming of them to
e fielde, they had caste
the project of this yeares exploites, according to
e nombers
which they receaved from her Ma
tie
and if all of them should
nowe be sent for awaye, considering they are come to handie
strokes w
th
the Enemye, there could nothing come of it, but
an evident overthrowe of theyr entreprise at
Groeningen
and of all theyr designes for all this yeare, w
th
the losse of all
theyr chardges, w
th
many apparant inconveniences to her
Ma
ties
great detriment aswell as theyr owne and the Enemies
most advantage: whereat
e people of this cuntry would
murmur out of measure; having strayned this yeare more
then ever before, to contribute to
e warres. To this
fol.158v
effect they discoursed w
th
very great earnestnesse, alleadging
dyvers other reasons: but concluded in substance in
e form
er:
which I endevoured to avoyde by urging
e importance of
succouring
Brest,
and by manifesting to
em
e benefit
if
t
went farre before this of theyr present exploite; and
t
aswell in respect of
e trafficke of theyr people as of her
Ma
ties
subjects: prooving allso unto them
t
e Enemie at
this
p
nt
is farre weaker in fielde
en he hath been these ma
ny
yeares, and
e
Provinces
armie every waye stronger,
wherby
e companies demaunded might be spared well
enough, and no suche danger come of it as they did p
re-
tend. But in conclusion upon shewe
t
they made of noe
satisfaction, howsoever I replyed, although it were w
th
inti-
mation,
t
there would be order taken for remboursing the
ir
Charges about
e 1500 men. I lett them plainely unders
tand
t
for
e
Normandie
Companies, and
e rest
t
were here
in
her Ma
ties
paye, she had fully determined to have them p
la-
ced in
Ostende
Flushing and
e
Brille,
for supply of these
bandes w
ch
were to goe away presently. And as for those
at
they had raised, and were payed by
e Provinces, if they h
ad
an intention to continue them here, the best waye to obtayn
yt at her Ma
ties
handes, was by arming out of hand some
good quantitie of shipping to accompanie
t
navie which
her Ma
tie
prepareth, which I thought they might perfor
m
very largely and w
th
ease, beyng bownd therunto by vertu
e of
e Treatie. After conference in this manner for a goo
d
whyle together, they returned to theyr college, w
th
report of m
y
speeches, and resolved there amonge themselves to make the
ir
aunswere by l
re
which I send hereinclosed wth a transc
ript
of it to yo
r
L: Wherein they offer for Ostend some compa
nies
of Dutche, which they of
Zeland
shall send thither, and a
compa-
nie of Englishe to be put into Vlissing, which they will s
end
from
e Campe. The Brille they are perswaded hath
e least
neede of all, but yet they promise to fournish both it and
e
rest w
th
greater nombers from
e Campe, as theyr necessitie
shall requyre. And as touching shippes of warre, for a
s
muche as theyr authoritie will not stretche to take order w
th
ou
t
theyr superiors they have written about it to every severa
ll
fol.159r
Province, whome they promise to sollicite soe often and soe earn-
nestly, as they hope to have theyr aunswer in lesse then a
fortenight to her Ma
ties
good lyking. In the meane season
they will send some shippes of warre, to
e Coast of Britanie
which shall presently putt to Sea, to take good information
of
e Enemies proceeding, wherby they maye be able to direct
theyr course
e better in joyning theyr forces w
th
her
Ma
ties
fleete, and in making theyr Provision.
For myne owne opinion of this awnsweare, considering
t
e
peace makers here are so busie amonge them
t
they growe
in greate hope of recovering
Groeningen,
that her Ma
ties
garrisons are indiferently provyded by suche meanes as
they propose, and
t
they yealde to come w
th
shipping to joine
w
th
her Ma
tie
, wherunto they are not tyed by strickt constructi
o
of
e Contract although they except not yet against it
I can not but surcease to presse them any further, untill
I heare how her Ma
tie
doth accepte of theyr letter, intending
till then to remayne at the Hadghe, hoping also by
t
tyme,
to understaunde from this assemblie, what assistaunce by sea
will be graunted by
e Provinces: in which regarde I would
be gladde to returne w
th
some aunsweare to her Ma
ties
con-
tent. But it will be very requisite to be signified unto
me, what number of shippes of warre are to goe from her Ma
tie
,
because I doe insiste
t
according to
e treatie they should arme
as many more; soe
e nomber exceede not
e
Prince of Oranges
offer made to
M
r
Dyar
in
e yeare 84. And because yt
seemed
w
th
by
e speeches which I had laste w
th
your L.
t
you
wanted a coppie
t
you wanted a coppie
of
t
which passed
at
t
tyme, I have sent you one herein. Those l
re
s
of credence w
ch
I had from her Ma
tie
to
e
Count Maurice
and
S
r
Frauncis Vere
, I have sent to
e Campe w
th
sufficient
advertisement of her pleasure about
e Companies, which
I thought very necessary to be presently imparted, to
e ende they
may not thincke
t
e warning is to suddaine, if heereafter
they be mooved, to send home greater nombers, then
e states at
this present are willinge to dismisse. I doe not certefie yo
r
L: howe
e motion of Peace hath hitherto succeded nor of
e
occurrences of Groeninghen, w
th
dyvers other matters, of w
ch
M
r
Gilpin
hath written before and will informe you
fol.159v
l
re
unto my L. T
re
r 26 May 1594.
at this present in particular manner. Yet I can not
in
duetie forbeare to make knowen,
t
at my co
m
ing to Flu
shing
I founde,
t
all
e
Companies
Captaynes were absent i
n
England,
S
r
Edmund Udall
excepted, which I thought i
n a
garrison of
t
chardge and account an exceeding great
disor-
der.
And thus beseeching you most humbly,
to
acquaynt her Ma
tie
w
th
e Course, which I have h
eld
in my businesse, and to make me allwayes as happy,
as yow have don heretofore, w
th
protesting my proceeding
w
th
your honorable favour I take my humble leave.
From
e Haghe May 26 1594.
Your L. most humble at Co
m
aundement Tho: Bodley
The bearer hereof M
r
Chamberlaine had very small
occasion to goe into
England,
but yet at my intrea
ty
because I wanted a messenger, he hath promised to de
liver
this letter to your L: with all
e speede
t
may be./
